title: Commonality in Pelvic Anatomy among Three Fossorial, Scratch-Digging, Mammalian Species
abstract: This study tests whether three species of fossorial, scratch-digging mammals-Dasypus novemcinctus, Ictidomys tridecemlineatus, and Taxidea taxusshow commonality in pelvic anatomies inferred to be adaptive for this behavior and, correspondingly, divergence in these anatomies from nonfossorial species. The fossorial and nonfossorial species are in the same superorder or family; the comparative sets of species are D. novemcinctus with Bradypus variegatus and Choloepus hoffmanni, I. tridecemlineatus with Sciurus carolinensis, and Ta. taxus with Gulo gulo, Martes americana, and Neovison vison. Fossorial species are hypothesized to show higher prevalence of fusion of sacroiliac and sacroischial (if present) joints, reduction in size or loss of pelvic symphysis, greater number of sacral vertebrae, greater number of vertebrae in articulation with ilium and ischium, and longer ischium. Only males were used in the study; total sample size was 318 adults and 135 subadults. Results show commonality among fossorial species in greater number of sacral vertebrae and rigidity of the pelvis. One inconsistency with expectations is that the pelvic symphysis in fossorial species is as sturdy as in nonfossorial species, based on prevalence of symphyseal fusion and relative length and breadth of pelvic symphysis. Greater number of sacral vertebrae may be due to assimilation of a lumbar vertebra(−e) with the sacrum in fossorial species associated with their slow running speed. A rigid pelvis, due to fusion of pelvic joints and relatively longer or broader pelvic symphysis, effectively transfers forces between vertebral column and hind limb.

abstract.text: This study tests whether three species of fossorial, scratch-digging mammals-Dasypus novemcinctus, Ictidomys tridecemlineatus, and Taxidea taxusshow commonality in pelvic anatomies inferred to be adaptive for this behavior and, correspondingly, divergence in these anatomies from nonfossorial species. The fossorial and nonfossorial species are in the same superorder or family; the comparative sets of species are D. novemcinctus with Bradypus variegatus and Choloepus hoffmanni, I. tridecemlineatus with Sciurus carolinensis, and Ta. taxus with Gulo gulo, Martes americana, and Neovison vison. Fossorial species are hypothesized to show higher prevalence of fusion of sacroiliac and sacroischial (if present) joints, reduction in size or loss of pelvic symphysis, greater number of sacral vertebrae, greater number of vertebrae in articulation with ilium and ischium, and longer ischium. Only males were used in the study; total sample size was 318 adults and 135 subadults. Results show commonality among fossorial species in greater number of sacral vertebrae and rigidity of the pelvis. One inconsistency with expectations is that the pelvic symphysis in fossorial species is as sturdy as in nonfossorial species, based on prevalence of symphyseal fusion and relative length and breadth of pelvic symphysis. Greater number of sacral vertebrae may be due to assimilation of a lumbar vertebra(−e) with the sacrum in fossorial species associated with their slow running speed. A rigid pelvis, due to fusion of pelvic joints and relatively longer or broader pelvic symphysis, effectively transfers forces between vertebral column and hind limb.

body_text.text: samples of these fossorial scratch-diggers, and based on that survey this study selected one species of armadillo (D. novemcinctus), badger (Ta. taxus), and ground squirrel (I. tridecemlineatus) for analysis. Hildebrand and Goslow (2001:457) described armadillos as among the Bmost powerful of scratch-diggers. .. , badgers. .. (as) fossorial. .. , and [g]round squirrels. .. (as) avid diggers.^Hildebrand (1985) stated that other species are able to dig well but are not considered to be fossorial; correspondingly, these species are not included in this study. A nonexhaustive list of these nonfossorial diggers includes platypuses, shrews, pikas, marmots, kangaroo rats, dogs, and bears.

In addition to the descriptive explanation of biomechanical adaptation to fossoriality, Hildebrand (1985:97-98, Table 6-2) presented indices that quantify two of these adaptations: olecranon process length/ulnar length (OPL/UL) and width between epicondyles of humerus/humeral length (HW/HL). High values for the indices imply musculoskeletal advantage of the forelimb for digging: (1) OPL/ULrelatively long lever arm for the extensor muscles of the forearm, and (2) HW/HLrelatively large area for attachment of flexor and extensor muscles of the digits and forefeet. Hildebrand (1985) stated that fossorial species have higher indices than nonfossorial species, although fossorial species are variable in the magnitude of the indices. Hopkins and Davis (2009) , however, reported no significant difference between fossorial (n = 38) and nonfossorial (n = 50) mammalian species in these indices, as well as in two other indices. Samuels and Van Valkenburgh (2008) argued that phylogenetic history is an important consideration in analyses to distinguish locomotor modes among mammals, including fossoriality, and they suggested that analyses be done at the level of family or order. Reanalysis of Hopkins and Davis' data (2009: supplementary appendix I) shows that OPL/UL better distinguishes fossorial species from nonfossorial species than HW/HL at the level of the family and sometimes at the level of order and superorder. Based on OPL/UL, this reanalysis shows the following with respect to the three fossorial species in this study: (1) D. novemcinctus has a higher index than all five nonfossorial species in Xenarthra, including one nonfossorial species in Dasypodidae; (2) I. tridecemlineatus has a higher index than 15 of 24 nonfossorial species in Rodentia, including all eight nonfossorial species in Sciuridae; and (3) Ta. taxus has a higher index than all five nonfossorial species in Carnivora, including all three nonfossorial species in Mustelidae.

This study considers whether D. novemcinctus, I. tridecemlineatus, and Ta. taxus show convergence in pelvic anatomies inferred to be adaptive for fossorial scratch-digging. Davis (1964) and Hildebrand (1985) identified several pelvic anatomies of mammalian diggers that differ from nondiggers and that they considered to be fossorial adaptations, including greater number of fused vertebrae in the sacrum, greater number of sacral vertebrae participating in the sacroiliac joint, fusion of sacroiliac joint, fusion of sacroischial joint (if present), weakness or absence of pelvic symphysis, and long ischium. The functional significance of these anatomies for fossorial mammals is as follows. A long sacrum increases surface area for attachment of extensor muscles of the vertebral column (e.g., multifidus and sacrospinalis; Davis 1964) . These muscles resist the tendency for flexion of the vertebral column during scratch-digging. A long sacrum may also provide pelvic rigidity because of either osseous contact between sacrum and ischium or shorter ligaments connecting the bones (Shockey et al. 2007) . Increase in number of vertebrae articulating with the hipbones enhances pelvic stability (Bryant 1945; Davis 1964) . Fusion of the sacrum with the ilium and ischium provides a rigid connection between the vertebral column and hind limbs for transmission of forces engendered by digging (Chapman 1919) . Weakening or loss of the pelvic symphysis is an obstetrical adaptation to increase pelvic capacity for birth in species with sacroiliac and, if present, sacroischial joint fusion (Chapman 1919) . A long ischium lengthens the lever arm for the extensor muscles of the thigh, which are used for pushing or kicking dirt and for stabilizing the pelvis when the hind limbs brace the body during digging.

This study tests whether three fossorial species show convergence and, correspondingly, divergence from nonfossorial species in the same superorder or family for prevalence of fusion of sacroiliac, sacroischial (if present), and pelvic symphyseal joints, number of sacral vertebrae, number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium and ischium, length and breadth of the pelvic symphysis, and length of the ischium. The comparative sets of fossorial and nonfossorial species are:

(1) D. novemcinctus, Bradypus variegatus (Pilosa: Bradypodidae; brown-throated sloth), and Choloepus hoffmanni (Pilosa: Megalonychidae; Hoffmann's two-toed sloth), with the three species in superorder Xenarthra; (2) I. tridecemlineatus and Sciurus carolinensis (Rodentia: Sciuridae; eastern gray squirrel); and (3) Ta. taxus, Gulo gulo (Carnivora: Mustelidae; wolverine), Martes americana (Carnivora: Mustelidae; American marten), and Neovison vison (Carnivora: Mustelidae; American mink). There are two reasons why the xenarthran species are not from the same family. First, researchers disagree about whether there are nonfossorial armadillos. Of the 21 species in Dasypodidae (Gardner 2005) , which is the only family in Cingulata, only Tolypeutes matacus (southern three-banded armadillo) and To. tricinctus (Brazilian three-banded armadillo) are reported to be nonfossorial (Schaller 1983; Abba and Superina 2010; Smith 2012) , with Redford (1994:7) asserting that BT [o] . matacus. .. does not dig its own burrows.^Although Santos et al. (1994:12) described these two species as Bthe poorest diggers of the armadillos,^Meritt (1973) reported that To. matacus digs burrows, and Attias et al. (2016:5) wrote that, Bour direct observations demonstrate that, like all other armadillo species, Tolypeutes do dig their own burrows.^Second, there was limited availability of Tolypeutes specimens. An online survey of museum collections in North America showed that the number of potentially available specimens that fulfilled the criteria for inclusion in the study (see below) was four for To. matacus and zero for To. tricinctus. In contrast, the potential availability of B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni specimens was 13 and 10, respectively.

Researchers have characterized D. novemcinctus, I. tridecemlineatus, and Ta. taxus as fossorial, semi-fossorial, and scratch-digger (Talmage and Buchanan 1954; Long 1973; Van Valkenburgh 1985; Vizcaíno et al. 1999; Hildebrand and Goslow 2001; Lagaria and Youlatos 2006; Kley and Kearney 2007; Fabre et al. 2015; Kilbourne 2017) . Researchers have described the other six species as follows: B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni are arboreal, with quadrupedal suspensory posture and locomotion (Nyakatura 2012; Pant et al. 2014; Pujos et al. 2017) ; S. carolinensis is arboreal and scansorial (Bangs 1896; Koprowski 1994; Dececchi and Larsson 2011) ; G. gulo is generalized in locomotion, scansorial, and terrestrial (Van Valkenburgh 1985; Fabre et al. 2015; Kilbourne 2017) ; M. americana is scansorial and largely arboreal (Cory 1912; Kilbourne 2017) ; and N. vison is natatorial, semi-aquatic, and terrestrial (Fabre et al. 2015; Botton-Divet et al. 2016; Kilbourne 2017) . Based on OPL/UL, D. novemcinctus has a higher index than C . h o f f m a n n i ( 0 . 4 2 5 a n d 0 . 0 8 8 , r e s p e c t i v e l y ) , I. tridecemlineatus has a higher index than S. carolinensis (0.219 and 0.187, respectively), and Ta. taxus has a higher index than G. gulo and M. americana (0.295, 0.210, and 0.193, respectively; Hopkins and Davis 2009: supplementary appendix I; data not available for B. variegatus and N. vison).

Some pelvic anatomies for the species in this study have been reported previously: (1) sacroiliac joint is Bcommonlyf used in sloths (Flower 1885:324), fused among males in D . n o v e m c i n c t u s , b u t u n f u s e d a m o n g m a l e s i n S. carolinensis (Tague 2016); (2) sacroischial joint is fused in sloths (Pujos et al. 2017 Leach and de Kleer 1978) , and between two and four in S. carolinensis (92% have three sacral vertebrae; Thorington 1972); and (5) number of vertebrae fused with the ilium is three in D. novemcinctus (Alves et al. 2017; Galliari and Carlini 2018) and four or five in B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni (Galliari and Carlini 2018) , and number of vertebrae fused with the ischium is four in D. novemcinctus (Alves et al. 2017) .

The hypotheses in this study are that D. novemcinctus, I. tridecemlineatus, and Ta. taxus will show commonality in the following pelvic anatomies when compared to the nonfossorial species: (1) fusion of sacroiliac and, if present, sacroischial joints; (2) reduction in size or loss of pelvic symphysis; (3) greater number of sacral vertebrae and of vertebrae articulating with the ilium and ischium (if sacroischial joint is present); and (4) longer ischium.

All specimens were from museum osteology collections. Museum records were consulted for species assignation, sex, and locality from where specimens were collected. No captive specimen was used. Only males were used to avoid the potential confounding influence of obstetrical adaptation on pelvic anatomy. Table 1 shows sample size for each species.

Specimens were categorized as adult or subadult based on fusion of proximal and distal epiphyses to the diaphyses of long bones, including left and right humeri, radii, ulnae, femora, tibiae, and fibulae. An epiphysis was recorded as being fused if there was at least one locus of unequivocal confluence of bone between epiphysis and diaphysis. A specimen was designated as adult if proximal and distal epiphyses were fused to the diaphysis of either the left or right side of the humerus, femur, either radius or ulna, and either tibia or fibula. If any of the 24 epiphyses (i.e., proximal and distal epiphyses of left and right sides of six long bones) was not fused to the diaphysis, then the specimen was designated as subadult. Among the 318 adult specimens, 308 showed fusion of both proximal and distal epiphyses of either the left or right side of all six long bones, eight had fusion of five of the bones, and two had fusion of four bones. Among these 318 specimens, 197 showed fusion of all 24 epiphyses. Due to missing bones, duplicate set of bones (of which neither set was used), and damage or tissue precluding assessment of epiphyseal fusion, the remaining 121 specimens showed fusion of between 12 and 23 epiphyses.

Only adults were used to determine pelvic joint fusion, number of sacral vertebrae, relative length and breadth of pelvic symphysis, and relative length of ischium. A pelvic joint was recorded as fused if there was at least one locus of unequivocal confluence of bone between sacrum and ilium, sacrum and ischium, or left and right pelvic symphyseal faces. Number of sacral vertebrae was simply the number of fused vertebrae, without distinction as to whether a lumbar or caudal vertebra(−e) was assimilated with the sacrum.

Subadults were used to determine number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium and ischium. These vertebrae are not referred to as sacral because for a number of specimens the vertebrae had not yet fused with one another. Among the available subadult specimens, only those were used in the study for which the lateral processes of adjoining vertebrae were not fully fused with one another so that the number of vertebrae in articulation with the ilium and ischium was unequivocal. If there was asymmetry between left and right sides in number of vertebrae in articulation, then the higher number was reported. Three specimens showed asymmetry in number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium and one specimen with the ischium.

Four measurements were taken: lengths of ilium, ischium, and pelvic symphysis ( Fig. 1a , A-B and C-D, and Fig. 1b , E-F, respectively), and breadth of pelvic symphysis (maximum ventrodorsal diameter of symphysis). Measurements were taken to the nearest 0.1 mm with dial calipers. Three indices were computed: (1) relative length of pelvic symphysis = length of pelvic symphysis/length of ilium; (2) relative breadth of pelvic symphysis = breadth of pelvic symphysis/length of ilium; and (3) relative length of ischium = length of ischium/length of ilium.

SPSS v25 (© IBM, Armonk, NY) was used for statistical analyses: (1) chi-square test and Fisher's exact test to compare species for difference in frequencies of sacroiliac, sacroischial, and pelvic symphyseal joint fusion, number of sacral vertebrae, and number of vertebrae articulating with ilium and ischium, and (2) ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis test, Mann-Whitney test, Student's t test, and Welch's t' test to compare species for difference in relative length and breadth of pelvic symphysis and relative length of ischium. For nominal level data, chi-square test was used when expected contingency cell frequencies were greater than five; otherwise, Fisher's exact test was used. For interval level data, ANOVA and Student's t test were used when sample size was ≥25 for each sample, but Welch's t' test was used if samples differed significantly in their variances; if sample size was <25 for at least one sample, Kruskal-Wallis and Mann-Whitney tests were used. Partition analysis was used as a post hoc procedure to ascertain if a significant difference among ≥ three species was due to the fossorial species being significantly different from the nonfossorial species; nonfossorial species were not compared with one another in partition analysis as this study dealt with commonality among fossorial species and difference between fossorial and nonfossorial species. Level of significance was set at p ≤ 0.05 (Q). This study performed 42 (m) statistical tests (BST,^which are numbered consecutively in Results), which increased the likelihood of Type I error. Therefore, this level of significance was adjusted using Benjamini and Hochberg's (1995) procedure (and this procedure is robust even when the multiple tests are not independent of one another; Benjamini and Yekutieli 2001) . Benjamini and Hochberg's (1995) procedure is as follows. The adjusted critical level of significance for each ST equals (i/m)Q, where i = rank of the unadjusted p value for that ST among all 42 STs. Table 2 presents the unadjusted and adjusted critical level of significance for each ST, as well as results of all statistical analyses. ST is significant if its unadjusted p is ≤ its adjusted critical p. Two-tailed test of significance was used for all analyses because this study evaluated commonality in anatomy among fossorial species, and results may have shown commonality but of opposite polarity from hypotheses.

The dataset analyzed for this study is available as Online Resource 1 (ESM 1) with the published article. Table 3 presents prevalence of fusion of pelvic joints, and Fig. 2 shows pelvic joint fusion for the fossorial species, D. novemcinctus, I. tridecemlineatus, and Ta. taxus. For the sacroiliac joint, 0% of sciurids and 100% of xenarthrans show fusion. Mustelids show a significant difference among species in sacroiliac joint fusion (p < 0.001, ST 1, Table 2 ). Whereas 51% of Ta. taxus show sacroiliac joint fusion, only 0.7% (1 of 140) of the other three species combined show fusion. In this study, only xenarthrans show a sacroischial joint. Xenarthrans are nonsignificantly different in prevalence of sacroischial fusion (p = 0.088, ST 2, Table 2), with 100% of D. novemcinctus and B. variegatus and 67% of C. hoffmanni showing fusion. For prevalence of pelvic symphyseal joint fusion, mustelids and sciurids show a significant difference (p < 0.001, ST 3, p = 0.001, ST 4, respectively, Table 2), but xenarthrans show a nonsignificant difference (p = 0.206, ST 5, Table 2 ). Among mustelids, 65% of Ta. taxus, 63% of N. vison, 43% of M. americana, and 14% of G. gulo show pelvic symphyseal ST is significant if unadjusted p ≤ adjusted critical p. SPSS returns a value of zero for Mann-Whitney test statistic when the species being compared do not overlap in the ranks for their variates fusion. For mustelids, partition analysis shows that Ta. taxus is nonsignificantly different from N. vison and M. americana in prevalence of pelvic symphyseal fusion but has a significantly higher prevalence than G. gulo (p = 0.844, ST 6, p = 0.059, ST 7, p < 0.001, ST 8, respectively, Table 2 ). Among mustelids, Ta. taxus shows 5%, 60%, and 35% with two, three, and four sacral vertebrae, respectively; G. gulo shows 93% and 7% with three and four sacral vertebrae, respectively; M. americana shows 2% and 98% with one and two sacral vertebrae, respectively; and N. vison shows 100% with three sacral vertebrae. Partition analysis shows that Ta. taxus has significantly the greatest number of sacral vertebrae among the mustelids: Ta. taxus compared to G. gulo, M. americana, and N. vison (p = 0.004, ST 12, p < 0.001, ST 13 and 14, respectively, Table 2 ). Ictidomys tridecemlineatus has a greater number of sacral vertebrae than S. carolinensis: for I. tridecemlineatus, 38% and 62% have three and four sacral vertebrae, respectively, whereas for S. carolinensis, 96% and 4% have three and four sacral vertebrae, respectively. Among

xenarthrans, D. novemcinctus shows 4%, 36%, and 60% with seven, eight, and nine sacral vertebrae, respectively; B. variegatus shows 75% and 25% with six and seven sacral vertebrae, respectively; and C. hoffmanni shows 33% and 67% with six and seven sacral vertebrae, respectively. For xenarthrans, partition analysis shows that D. novemcinctus has significantly the greatest number of sacral vertebrae: D. novemcinctus compared to B. variegatus and to C. hoffmanni (p < 0.001, ST 15, p = 0.001, ST 16, respectively, Table 2 ). Table 5 presents number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium and ischium. Mustelids and sciurids show no significant difference between fossorial and nonfossorial species in number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium (p = 0.098, ST 17, p = 0.421, ST 18, respectively, Table 2 ). Neither mustelids nor sciurids have a sacroischial joint. Xenarthrans show a significant difference in number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium and ischium (p < 0.001, ST 19 and 20, Table 2 ). Partition analysis shows that D. novemcinctus has significantly fewer vertebrae articulating with the ilium (85% and 15% with three and four vertebrae, respectively) than does B. variegatus (80% and 20% with four and five vertebrae, respectively; p = 0.001, ST 21, Table 2 ). The one C. hoffmanni specimen has five vertebrae articulating with the ilium. For the sacroischial joint, partition analysis shows that D. novemcinctus has a significantly greater number of vertebrae in articulation (29% and 71% with three and four vertebrae, respectively) than B. variegatus (60% and 40% with one and two vertebrae, respectively; p < 0.001, ST 22, a For sacroiliac and sacroischial joints, specimens were included in analysis only if both left and right sides of joint could be evaluated. For sacroiliac joint, six specimens showed asymmetry in fusion of the joint (i.e., one side of the joint was fused but the other side was not fused); these specimens were recorded as having sacroiliac joint fusion Table 2 ). The one C. hoffmanni specimen has two vertebrae articulating with the ischium. Table 6 presents summary statistics for length and breadth of pelvic symphysis and lengths of ilium and ischium, and Table 7 presents summary statistics for indices of relative length and breadth of pelvic symphysis and relative length of ischium. Mustelids show a significant difference in both relative length and breadth of the pelvic symphysis (p < 0.001, ST 23 and 24, Table 2 ). Partition analysis shows that Ta. taxus has significantly the lowest index of relative pelvic symphyseal length but the highest index of relative pelvic symphyseal breadth (p < 0.001, ST 25-30, Table 2 ). For sciurids, I. tridecemlineatus has a significantly higher index of relative pelvic symphyseal length than S. carolinensis (p = 0.038, ST 31, Table 2 ). Xenarthrans show a significant difference in relative pelvic symphyseal length (p = 0.015, ST 32, Table 2 ). Partition analysis shows that D. novemcinctus has a significantly higher index of relative pelvic symphyseal length than B. variegatus but does not differ significantly from C. hoffmanni (p = 0.011, ST 33, p = 0.080, ST 34, respectively, Table 2 ). Sample sizes are too small to compare sciurids and xenarthrans for relative pelvic symphyseal breadth. For relative ischial length, results show significant differences among mustelids, between sciurids, and among xenarthrans (p < 0.001, ST 35 and 36, p = 0.011, ST 37, respectively, Table 2 ). For sciurids, I. tridecemlineatus has a relatively shorter ischium than S. carolinensis. Among mustelids, partition analysis shows that Ta. taxus is nonsignificantly different from G. gulo in relative ischial length but has a significantly lower index than both M. americana and N. vison (p = 0.150, ST 38, p < 0.001, ST 39 and 40, respectively, Table 2 ). Among xenarthrans, partition analysis shows that D. novemcinctus has a significantly higher index of relative ischial length than B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni (p < 0.001, ST 41, p = 0.006, ST 42, respectively, Table 2 ).

Results of this study for pelvic joint fusion and for numbers of sacral vertebrae and vertebrae articulating with the ilium and ischium are generally in accord with those of previous studies (see above). This study considers whether three fossorial, scratch-digging, mammalian species show commonality in pelvic anatomy when compared with nonfossorial species in the same family or superorder. Table 8 summarizes the results of this study and shows that the scratch-diggers have one commonality when compared to the nonfossorial speciesgreater number of sacral vertebrae. Three interpretations are offered for a greater number of sacral vertebrae in scratch-diggers. First, Davis (1964) argued that the sacrum is longer by assimilation of one or more caudal vertebrae to increase the surface area for attachment of extensor muscles of the vertebral column, which resist vertebral a Small sample size or absence of specimens for pelvic symphyseal breadth due to curvature of articulated pelvic symphysis that precluded measurement flexion during scratch-digging. Bryant (1945:291) , however, considered the four segment sacrum in some sciurids, such as I. tridecemlineatus, to be due to an Bextra bone and not first caudal fused into (the) sacral complex,^when compared with the three segment sacrum in other sciurids, such as S. carolinensis. Bryant (1945) did not explain the etiology of the extra sacral vertebra. This study did not count the total number of vertebrae for each specimen to determine whether the greater number of sacral vertebrae in the fossorial species compared to the nonfossorial species is due to additional somite segmentation or homeotic transformation. Second, Shockey et al. (2007) suggested that a longer sacrum provides pelvic stability by bringing the sacrum closer to the ischium, enabling either osseous contact or shorter ligament connecting the two bones. The long sacrum in D. novemcinctus does provide pelvic stability as 100% (n = 27) of the specimens in this study have sacroischial joint fusion. However, as 86% (six of seven) of the combined sample of B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni also have sacroischial joint fusion, sacral length in D. novemcinctus is more likely a derivative of that species' long ischium (see below). Shockey et al.'s (2007) explanation for the longer sacrum in fossorial species cannot be evaluated for I. tridecemlineatus and Ta. taxus because this study neither measured the distance between the apex of the sacrum and ischium nor collected observational data on rugosity of the ligamentous attachment between sacrum and ischium. Third, the longer sacrum in I. tridecemlineatus and Ta. taxus is an epiphenomenon of assimilation of a lumbar vertebra(−e) with the sacrum by anterior homeotic transformation associated with relatively slow locomotion. Galis et al. (2014) reported that slow species have higher intraspecific variability in number of presacral vertebrae compared to fast species because slow species are subject to less intense selection pressure against anterior homeotic transformation of presacral vertebrae. Notably, Galis et al. (2014: dataset S2) reported that the Asian and European badger (Meles, serving here as proxy for the American badger, Ta. taxus) is a slow runner and has higher variability in number of presacral vertebrae than 14 of 15 other genera of carnivorans, and Iriarte-Díaz (2002:2899, Table 1 ) reported that I. tridecemlineatus is in the lower quartile for maximum relative running speed among 50 species of rodents (S. carolinensis is in the upper-middle quartile). However, the longer sacrum in D. novemcinctus compared to B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni cannot be similarly explained because the sloths are slow quadrupeds. The sacrum in D. novemcinctus may be long because of its articulation with the long ischium. An interesting result of this study is that the fossorial species have either a fully rigid or a more rigid pelvis than the nonfossorial species. Dasypus novemcinctus has a fully rigid pelvis; all specimens show fusion of the sacroiliac, sacroischial, and pelvic symphyseal joints. Taxidea taxus is distinctive among mustelids in sacroiliac joint fusion, and a majority of specimens have fusion of the sacroiliac and pelvic symphyseal joints. Finally, I. tridecemlineatus has a higher frequency of pelvic symphyseal joint fusion than S. carolinensis. This commonality among the fossorial species in pelvic rigidity may be an example of convergence in function despite morphological difference (Losos 2011) . The functional significance of pelvic rigidity for scratch-diggers is transmission of force between vertebral column and hind limbs through the sacroiliac joint with no or limited pelvic joint displacement. (Pelvic symphyseal fusion restricts mobility of an unfused sacroiliac joint [pers. obs.] .) However, a conclusion that fossorial scratch-diggers show convergence in functional rigidity of the pelvis is tempered for two reasons. First, as the fossorial species differ in the constellation of pelvic joint fusions, the implication is that the species differ in the magnitude of force transmitted through the pelvis associated with digging and/or in the frequency of digging.

Although assessing degree of fossoriality among species without consideration of phylogenetic history can be problematic (see above), D. novemcinctus, I. tridecemlineatus, and Ta. taxus differ in their OPL/UL ratios, which is consistent with an inference that they differ in the force and/or frequency of digging. Among 38 fossorial species in Hopkins and Davis (2009: supplementary appendix I), D. novemcinctus, Ta. taxus, and I. tridecemlineatus have the 5th, 9th, and 24th highest indices, respectively. Second, although a majority of I. tridecemlineatus and Ta. taxus show fusion of the pelvic symphysis and, in Ta. taxus, sacroiliac joint, these species are not universal in fusion for either joint as is D. novemcinctus. However, intraspecific variation in anatomy associated with fossoriality need not negate an interpretation of convergence. Rather, intraspecific variation may imply differences among individuals in digging ability. For example, Chaetophractus villosus (Cingulata: Dasypodidae; big hairy armadillo) shows sexual dimorphism in some anatomies of the humerus and ulna associated with fossoriality, with the implication of sexual difference in digging ability (Acuña et al. 2017 ; also see Christiansen and Fariña 2003) . Also, fossorial species of the African catfish (Siluriformes: Clariidae) have an elongated body, which is typically associated with absence of fins. Nevertheless, these species show intraspecific variation in presence or absence of pelvic and pectoral fins, which implies differences among individuals in burrowing ability (Adriaens et al. 2002) .

Results of this study show three inconsistencies with theoretical expectations. First, the fossorial species have sturdy pelvic symphyses, not short, weak, or absent symphyses. Prevalence rates for pelvic symphyseal fusion are 65%, 69%, and 100% in Ta. taxus, I. tridecemlineatus, and D. novemcinctus, respectively. The index of relative pelvic symphyseal length in D. novemcinctus and I. tridecemlineatus is either significantly higher or nonsignificantly different from that of nonfossorial species, and the relative pelvic symphyseal breadth of Ta. taxus is highest among mustelids. Second, fossorial species are not uniform in having a longer ischium than nonfossorial species. Ictidomys tridecemlineatus has a relatively shorter ischium than S. carolinensis, and Ta. taxus is either comparable with or has a relatively shorter ischium than the other mustelids. Third, I. tridecemlineatus and Ta. taxus do not have a greater number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium than the nonfossorial species. The reason may be that the fossorial species have greater sacroiliac joint stability than the nonfossorial species due to higher prevalence rates of fusion of the sacroiliac joint in Ta. taxus and pelvic symphysis in I. tridecemlineatus. Interestingly, although all xenarthrans in this study have sacroiliac joint fusion, B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni have a greater number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium than D. novemcinctus (also see Galliari and Carlini 2018) . The explanation for this inverse of the theoretical expectation may be in the sloths' distinctive mode of locomotion. Galliari and Carlini (2018) argued that the greater number of vertebrae in the sacroiliac joint in B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni is an ancestral trait, as well as is their broad ilium (Flower 1885), and both traits likely originated in a terrestrial ancestor. In evolution of the extant sloths, the elongated ilium remained selectively advantageous for attachment of an enlarged iliacus muscle. This muscle and other flexors of the hip counter passive hip extension due to gravitational force associated with the sloths' suspensory, quadrupedal locomotion (Nyakatura 2010) . The greater number of vertebrae in the sacroiliac joint of extant sloths is simply an epiphenomenal retention of an ancestral trait associated with the elongated ilium (Galliari and Carlini 2018) . B>^indicates fossorial species has higher prevalence rate or higher index than nonfossorial species; B<î ndicates fossorial species has lower prevalence rate or lower index than nonfossorial species

Two limitations of this study warrant clarification in future research. First, only a subset of subadult specimens in the museum collections was included in the studythose for which the lateral processes of the sacral vertebrae were not completely fused so that number of vertebrae articulating with the ilium and ischium could be determined. Future research could include all subadult specimens to determine whether fossorial and nonfossorial species differ in the sequence of epiphyseal fusion among long bones (but see Geiger et al. 2014) . Second, this study used a binary classification of specimens by age based on epiphyseal fusion of long bonessubadult or adult. An alternative approach is to assess dental age for specimens based on eruption and wear of teeth. This information would enable analysis of whether fossorial and nonfossorial species differ in the dental ages at which fusion of sacral vertebrae and pelvic joints occurs.

Follow-up studies are encouraged to answer two questions that will provide a fuller understanding of the evolution of pelvic rigidity in fossorial, scratch-digging species. First, is intraspecific variation in pelvic joint fusion among fossorial, scratch-digging species related to individual differences in digging ability, and if so, do these differences correlate with natural selective (dis)advantage? Second, pelvic joint fusion is not limited to fossorial species, so what are the functional and evolutionary bases for pelvic rigidity in nonfossorial species? For example, pelvic rigidity in B. variegatus and C. hoffmanni may be an ancestral trait, inherited from a facultatively bipedal or fossorial xenarthran ancestor (Winge 1941; Nyakatura 2012; Pujos et al. 2012; Patiño and Fariña 2017) . A nonexhaustive list of extant nonfossorial species with fusion of one or more pelvic joints (pelvic symphyseal, sacroiliac, and sacroischial) includes a number of species of bats within Anoura, Artibeus, Chrotopterus, Desmodus, Diaemus, Micronycteris, Noctilio, Pteronotus, and Sturnira, as well as Ailuropoda melanoleuca (giant panda), Castor canadensis (American beaver), Hylobates lar (lar gibbon), Macaca mulatta (rhesus monkey), Moschiola meminna (Indian spotted chevrotain), Presbytis rubicunda (maroon leaf-monkey), and Urocyon cinereoargenteus (gray fox) (Davis 1964; Altenbach 1979; Tague 1990 Tague , 1993 Tague , 2016 Simmons and Conway 2001; Gayathri et al. 2015; Gaudioso et al. 2017) .

In conclusion, three fossorial, scratch-digging species -D. novemcinctus, I. tridecemlineatus, and Ta. taxusshow commonality in sacral elongation when compared with nonfossorial species. The fossorial species also have a more rigid pelvis compared to the nonfossorial species, but interspecific differences among the fossorial species in the constellation and prevalence of pelvic joint fusion provide caution to an interpretation that fossorial species show convergence in functional rigidity of the pelvis. Contra generalizations that fossorial, scratch-digging species show convergence in pelvic anatomy, diggers are not uniform.
J Mammal Evol (2020) 27:315-327
